page.title: 07CONSERVATION - NORTH DOWNS
page.content: This is an important issue. Permanent damage to the landscape occurs as housing covers arable land and farmers in the interests of economy, use larger more efficient machines. Existing hedgerows are uprooted to give the equipment long, uninterrupted runs and room to manoeuvre. Along the North Downs Way centuries-old trees have been felled, creating large, featureless expanses. When fields are ploughed and planted, footpaths are lost, forever unless re-established, depriving people of the pleasures of the countryside. As the ecological balance is disturbed, indigenous species disappear. However, even M20 cutting slopes provide a natural habitat for animals and plants. Hawks are commoner and foreign seeds dropped from vehicles germinate along the verges.
